The Bioshock series is a good spiritual successor to System Shock. I wish they'd kept the "hacking" mechanic from the first two games, and/or made them somehow a connected storyline, but still it's a solid game.

Wonderful game.  I'm not usually a fan of first person shooters but really enjoyed the BioShock series.  It's not always just about the fighting(which is probably most peoples favorite part) it has interesting unique powers and they keep layering on abilities to make the combat different.  They are also tremendous about delivering on the jump scares (wow).  What truly makes the game is the original story and the way it is told so you are invested in the characters.

4/10

honestly i had high hopes for this game because i had heard great things! but the more nuanced things addressed in the game like racism arent given the attention they deserve. 

[spoiler] the twist at the end where you end up being the big bad racist? doesnt make sense and isnt compelling. [/spoiler] i wasnt able to get attached to either of the main characters. booker handles elizabeth horribly, and elizabeth herself is really annoying. i also found elizabeths character model kind of creepy? the eyes are too big so she looks like a rejected disney princess. 

i did enjoy the combat! i found a lot of it enjoyable but the ending felt so rushed.

"Would you recommend this game to other players?" asks the man in Valve every time I decide to write about my experience with a game once I'm finished. There have been games for which the answer was more complicated than a Yes or No, but this is the first time I have no clue what I should say.

Let's put the obvious out of the way. Great art direction, the game can be absolutely gorgeous to look at times, skyline combat is incredibly fun, Elizabeth is a great character and her AI is very solidly built, the soundtrack is good but nothing spectacular in my opinion. One bug I encountered more times than necessary was the game freezing my computer when I clicked exit to desktop after a longer session (90+ mins).


All that said, this is how I describe my experience with the game.


Gameplay - Absolutely horrendous. Bioshock Infinite is just another first person shooter from it's time period but set in a city in the clouds. The sky hook is a great addition, but the game fails to make use of it as often as I'd like. That could be excusable if the movement mechanics would be any good. You can't sprint sideways or backwards in this game, and there is not a perk to unlock it. The combat encounters are long ranged enough to warrant that sort of fast omni-directional movement instead of the default sluggish one. I want to play this game as a movement shooter because it's fun that way. The walking/running feels lifted straight out of CoD and I don't feel it's a fit for this kind of game. The AI is dumber than Bioshock 1, I played on hard and I straight up cheesed every human enemy by just smacking them in the face for funny. Possessing enemies was where the AI really shined. Possessed enemies would stand next to other enemies and just look at them awkwardly until the spell expired then either killed themselves or corrected the direction of their gaze (depending upon their type) more times than I can remember. All this to say without even mentioning the absurd 2 weapon limit which serves no purpose other than declining you the right gun when you need it. Vigors range from mostly useless to "I guess this can be considered cool" with no explanation for their existence provided until the story DLCs (an afterthought?). Which reminds me the weapon wheel is really badly implemented in the DLC. I couldn't even map it to my preferred button correctly for some weird reason. Also navigating any menu is cumbersome.
(Quick edit: No manual saves, all my homies hate when no manual saves).


Story - Either the game does a really bad job at explaining itself or there really are gaping plot-tears (see what I did there :P) in the story. Or I'm simply plain too dumb to get it. It is kinda cool though. If this wasn't a Bioshock game, I wouldn't have recommended it. The story is great from the parts I can actually understand but it can be really badly presented at certain times. I'll give an example, all Bioshock games convey a significant chunk of story via recorded voice diaries, hence these important bits and pieces of dialogue should be subtitled when I turn dialogue subs on. Except in Infinite they're not and every time Liz or a random enemy/NPC start to talk (or scream) while I'm listening to an audio diary I just picked up, the game makes the voxophone volume really low to prioritise NPC dialog and scripted SFX, as a result I miss half the diary. Then I replay it, stand still for the duration while praying to God nothing happens. It was annoying and I gave up looking for them halfway. Then there are the characters. Liz is the only one that stands out because of her writing, Luteces are fun because of their importance to the story and less because of the quality of their writing. Fink is okay for the most part, the crazed colonel in the Hall of Heroes is forgettable because I can't remember his name, Lady Comstock is straight up cringe, Daisy is boring, Comstock and Booker are boring outside of plot significance. Their is little to no nuance in most of the characters, something I dearly missed from the denizens of Rapture in Bioshock 1. In spite of all this the plot itself is pretty interesting, and quite endearing especially with how they bring it full circle with Burial at Sea 2. I may not know exactly how to feel about it personally, but it's not objectively bad, it's good but I can't say how good.


My experience with this game has been less than ideal, but a lot of people like this game so there is a high chance you'll like it too. I prolly won't play this game again, but I'd still recommend playing through it once and deciding how you feel about it yourself. I've been particularly harsh on the gameplay as I don't jive with it, but again I can't say the same for you. One thing that I can say for certain despite being a Bioshock title, it's nowhere close to an immersive sim.


[i]I get to wear this cute little thimble. I hear they're all the rage in Paris.[/i]
